docs.title: Tether.name
docs.text:
AI agent identity verification — so you know who you're talking to.

Tether lets AI agents prove their identity through cryptographic challenge-response verification. No passwords, no custodial keys — agents hold their own RSA private keys and sign challenges to prove they are who they say they are.

docs.title: For Users
docs.text: Want to verify an agent? Head to tether.name — no account needed. Click "Verify an Agent," send the challenge to the agent, and watch the result appear in real time.

docs.title: For Developers
docs.text:
Building an agent that needs to prove its identity? You're in the right place.

  • Quick Start

    Getting Started

  • SDKs

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
┌─────────┐         ┌──────────────┐         ┌─────────┐
│  Agent   │───1────▶│ api.tether   │◀───2────│  User   │
│          │         │   .name      │         │         │
│  Signs   │───3────▶│  Verifies    │───4────▶│  Sees   │
│ challenge│         │   proof      │         │ result  │
└─────────┘         └──────────────┘         └─────────┘
  1. User requests a challenge from Tether
  2. User sends the challenge to the agent
  3. Agent signs the challenge with its private key and submits proof
  4. Tether verifies the signature and shows the result

The private key never leaves the agent's machine.

docs.title: Install
CLI
docs.text: The Tether CLI lets you set up credentials, verify your agent's identity, and debug the challenge-response flow — all from the terminal.

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
npm install -g tether-name-cli

Or use without installing:

npx tether-name-cli verify

docs.title: tether init
docs.text:
Interactive setup wizard. Walks you through configuring your credential ID, private key path, and optionally generates a new RSA-2048 key pair.

tether init

This saves your configuration to ~/.tether/config.json.

If you choose to generate keys, it creates:

  • .tether-private-key.pem (private key, chmod 600)
  • .tether-public-key.pem (public key, for registering with Tether)

docs.title: tether verify
docs.text:
Perform a full identity verification — requests a challenge, signs it, submits proof, and displays the result.

tether verify

# Machine-readable output
tether verify --json

docs.title: tether status
docs.text:
Show your current configuration — credential ID (masked), key file path, and API URL.

tether status

tether status --json

docs.title: tether challenge
docs.text:
Request a new challenge code from the Tether API and print it.

tether challenge

docs.title: tether sign <challenge>
docs.text:
Sign a challenge string with your private key and print the proof.

tether sign "a1b2c3d4-e5f6-7890-abcd-ef1234567890"

docs.title: tether check <code>
docs.text:
Check the status of a challenge by its code.

tether check "a1b2c3d4-e5f6-7890-abcd-ef1234567890"

tether check "a1b2c3d4-e5f6-7890-abcd-ef1234567890" --json

docs.title: tether agent create <name>
docs.text:
Create a new agent. Requires an API key.

tether agent create "my-bot" --description "My helpful bot"

tether agent create "my-bot" --json

Returns the agent's ID, name, and a registration token (save it — it can't be retrieved later).

docs.title: tether agent list
docs.text:
List all agents associated with your API key.

tether agent list

tether agent list --json

docs.title: tether agent delete <id>
docs.text:
Delete an agent by its credential ID.

tether agent delete "credential-id-here"

tether agent delete "credential-id-here" --json

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
The CLI resolves configuration in this order (first wins):

  1. CLI flags — --credential-id, --key-path, --api-key
  2. Environment variables — TETHER_CREDENTIAL_ID, TETHER_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH, TETHER_API_KEY
  3. Config file — ~/.tether/config.json (created by tether init)

docs.title: Global Flags
docs.text: Flag Description --credential-id <id> Override credential ID --key-path <path> Override private key file path --api-key <key> API key for agent management operations --verbose Enable debug output --json Machine-readable JSON output (on supported commands)

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
# 1. Set up credentials
tether init

# 2. Check your config
tether status

# 3. Verify your identity
tether verify

# 4. Debug: manually request and sign a challenge
tether challenge
tether sign "the-challenge-code"
tether check "the-challenge-code"

docs.title: Agent Management
docs.text:
# Create an agent
tether agent create "my-bot" --description "My helpful assistant"

# List all agents
tether agent list

# Delete an agent
tether agent delete "credential-id"

Agent management commands require an API key. Set it via --api-key, the TETHER_API_KEY environment variable, or in your config file.

docs.title: MCP Server
docs.text: The Tether MCP server lets any MCP-compatible AI agent verify its identity without writing integration code. Just add it to your MCP config.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Required Description TETHER_CREDENTIAL_ID ✅ Your Tether credential ID TETHER_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH ✅ Path to RSA private key (DER or PEM)

docs.title: Security
docs.text: The private key stays on your machine. The MCP server reads it from a local file — it's never transmitted. The server runs as a local subprocess via STDIO.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• npm
  • GitHub

docs.title: Non-Custodial Design
docs.text:
Tether's core security principle: your private key never leaves your machine.

  • Agents generate their own RSA-2048 key pairs locally
  • Only the public key is uploaded to Tether during registration
  • The server never sees, stores, or transmits private keys
  • Signing happens entirely on the agent's machine

docs.title: Challenge-Response
docs.text:
Each verification uses a fresh, single-use challenge:

  • Challenges are UUID-based (122-bit entropy)
  • Each challenge can only be used once
  • Challenges are rate-limited per IP
  • Results are stored in Tether for the verification page to display

docs.title: What Tether Stores
docs.text:
• Your email address (for account authentication)
  • Agent names and credential IDs
  • RSA public keys (for signature verification)
  • Challenge results (challenge ID, verification status, timestamp)

docs.title: What Tether Does NOT Store
docs.text:
• Private keys
  • Passwords (there are none — auth is passwordless)
  • Chat logs or conversation content
  • Any data about what your agent does

docs.title: Recommendations
docs.text:
• Store private keys with restricted file permissions (chmod 600)
  • Use environment variables for credential IDs, not hardcoded values
  • Rotate keys periodically by creating new credentials
  • Add *.der, *.pem, and .env to your .gitignore

docs.title: Reporting Issues
docs.text: Found a security issue? Email jawnnypoo@gmail.com.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: The Tether API supports two authentication methods: JWT access tokens and API keys.

docs.title: Passwordless Auth
docs.text: Tether uses magic code authentication — no passwords.

docs.title: Request a Code
docs.text:
POST /auth/send-code
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "email": "you@example.com"
}

A magic code is sent to the provided email.

docs.title: Exchange Code for Tokens
docs.text:
POST /auth/verify-code
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "email": "you@example.com",
  "code": "123456"
}

Response:

{
  "accessToken": "eyJ...",
  "refreshToken": "eyJ..."
}

docs.title: Refresh Token
docs.text:
POST /auth/refresh
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "refreshToken": "eyJ..."
}

Response:

{
  "accessToken": "eyJ..."
}

docs.title: Using Access Tokens
docs.text:
Include the access token in the Authorization header:

Authorization: Bearer eyJ...

docs.title: Get Current User
docs.text:
GET /auth/me
Authorization: Bearer eyJ...

Returns the currently authenticated user's info.

docs.title: Logout
docs.text:
POST /auth/logout
Authorization: Bearer eyJ...

Invalidates the current session.

docs.title: API Keys
docs.text:
API keys are long-lived tokens for programmatic access. Use them to manage agents from CI/CD pipelines, scripts, or backend services without going through the magic code flow.

API keys use the sk-tether-name- prefix for easy identification and leak detection.

docs.title: Create an API Key
docs.text:
Requires JWT authentication.

POST /api-keys
Authorization: Bearer eyJ...
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "name": "CI Pipeline",
  "expiresInDays": 90
}

Response:

{
  "id": "key_abc123",
  "key": "sk-tether-name-...",
  "name": "CI Pipeline",
  "keyPrefix": "sk-tether-name-abc",
  "expiresAt": "2026-05-27T00:00:00.000Z",
  "createdAt": "2026-02-26T00:00:00.000Z"
}

Warning

The full key value is shown only once. Store it securely — the API stores only a hash.

docs.title: List API Keys
docs.text:
GET /api-keys
Authorization: Bearer eyJ...

Response:

[
  {
    "id": "key_abc123",
    "name": "CI Pipeline",
    "keyPrefix": "sk-tether-name-abc",
    "expiresAt": "2026-05-27T00:00:00.000Z",
    "createdAt": "2026-02-26T00:00:00.000Z",
    "lastUsedAt": "2026-02-26T12:00:00.000Z",
    "revoked": false
  }
]

docs.title: Revoke an API Key
docs.text:
DELETE /api-keys/{id}
Authorization: Bearer eyJ...

docs.title: Using API Keys
docs.text:
Include the API key in the Authorization header, just like a JWT:

Authorization: Bearer sk-tether-name-...

API keys can be used with all credential endpoints (/credentials/*). Creating and managing API keys themselves requires JWT authentication.

docs.title: Security Notes
docs.text:
• API keys are hashed before storage — they cannot be retrieved after creation.
  • The sk-tether-name- prefix enables automated leak detection in logs and repositories.
  • Revoked keys are rejected immediately.
  • Set expiresInDays to limit key lifetime. Omit for non-expiring keys.

docs.title: Public Endpoints
docs.text:
The following endpoints do not require authentication:

  • POST /challenge — Request a challenge
  • POST /challenge/verify — Submit proof
  • GET /check — Check challenge status

docs.title: Challenges
docs.text: Challenges are the core of Tether's verification flow. They are single-use, rate-limited, and expire after a short window.

docs.title: Request a Challenge
docs.text:
No authentication required.

POST /challenge
Content-Type: application/json

Response:

{
  "code": "a1b2c3d4-e5f6-7890-abcd-ef1234567890"
}

docs.title: Verify a Challenge
docs.text:
Submit a signed proof to verify an agent's identity. No authentication required.

POST /challenge/verify
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "challenge": "a1b2c3d4-e5f6-7890-abcd-ef1234567890",
  "proof": "url-safe-base64-signature",
  "credentialId": "your-credential-id"
}

Response (success):

{
  "verified": true,
  "agentName": "My Agent",
  "verifyUrl": "https://tether.name/check?challenge=a1b2c3d4...",
  "email": "owner@example.com",
  "registeredSince": "2026-01-15T00:00:00Z"
}

Response (failure):

{
  "verified": false,
  "error": "Invalid signature"
}

docs.title: Check Challenge Status
docs.text:
GET /check?challenge=a1b2c3d4-e5f6-7890-abcd-ef1234567890

Returns the current status of a challenge — whether it's been verified and by whom.

docs.title: Signing
docs.text:
The proof is an RSA-SHA256 signature of the challenge string, encoded as URL-safe base64 (no padding):

echo -n "$CHALLENGE" | openssl dgst -sha256 -sign private-key.der | base64 | tr '+/' '-_' | tr -d '='

docs.title: Credentials
docs.text: Credentials represent a registered agent. Each credential has a unique ID and an associated RSA public key.

docs.title: Create a Credential
docs.text:
Requires authentication (JWT or API key).

POST /credentials/issue
Authorization: Bearer eyJ...
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "agentName": "My Agent"
}

Response:

{
  "credentialId": "rgUOzbqar8z0Ag9RZH5I",
  "registrationToken": "one-time-token"
}

Warning

The registrationToken is shown only once. Save it — you'll need it to register your public key.

docs.title: Register a Public Key
docs.text:
No authentication required — uses the registration token instead.

POST /credentials/{credentialId}/register-key
Content-Type: application/json

{
  "registrationToken": "one-time-token",
  "publicKey": "-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----\n..."
}

Response:

{
  "registered": true
}

docs.title: Check Credential Status
docs.text:
Requires authentication (JWT or API key).

GET /credentials/{credentialId}/status
Authorization: Bearer eyJ...

Response:

{
  "registered": true
}

docs.title: List Credentials
docs.text:
Requires authentication (JWT or API key).

GET /credentials
Authorization: Bearer eyJ...

Returns an array of all credentials associated with your account.

docs.title: Delete a Credential
docs.text:
Requires authentication (JWT or API key).

DELETE /credentials/{credentialId}
Authorization: Bearer eyJ...

docs.title: Key Generation
docs.text:
Generate an RSA-2048 key pair for your agent:

# Generate private key (DER format)
openssl genpkey -algorithm RSA -pkeyopt rsa_keygen_bits:2048 -outform DER -out private-key.der

# Extract public key (PEM format for registration)
openssl rsa -in private-key.der -inform DER -pubout -out public-key.pem

Then register the public key contents with the endpoint above.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Tether.name provides identity verification for AI agents using RSA cryptographic challenge-response.

docs.title: Credentials
docs.text:
When you register an agent on tether.name, you receive a credential consisting of:

  • Credential ID — A unique identifier for your agent
  • Registration Token — A one-time token used to register your agent's public key

docs.title: Key Pairs
docs.text:
Each agent generates its own RSA-2048 key pair:

  • Private key — Stays on your agent's machine. Used to sign challenges. Never shared.
  • Public key — Uploaded to Tether during registration. Used to verify signatures.

docs.title: Challenges
docs.text: A challenge is a UUID-based code (122-bit entropy) that Tether generates for each verification attempt. The agent signs the challenge with its private key, and Tether verifies the signature against the registered public key.

docs.title: Security Model
docs.text:
• Non-custodial — Tether never sees your private key. Your agent generates the key pair and only uploads the public key.
  • No replay attacks — Each challenge is single-use and rate-limited.
  • Traceable — Every agent links back to a verified email address.

docs.title: Flow
docs.text:
1. Register — Create an account on tether.name, name your agent, and receive credentials
  2. Generate keys — Your agent generates an RSA-2048 key pair and registers the public key with Tether
  3. Verify — When challenged, your agent signs the challenge with its private key and submits the proof

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Register your agent
  • Quick start guide

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get your agent verifying its identity in under 5 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A Tether credential (register here)
  • Your agent's private key file

docs.title: Verify Identity
Responding to a Challenge
docs.text:
When a user sends your agent a challenge code, sign and submit it:

Node.jsPythonGoCLI 
const challenge = "the-challenge-code-from-user";
const proof = client.sign(challenge);
const result = await client.submitProof(challenge, proof);

challenge = "the-challenge-code-from-user"
proof = client.sign(challenge)
result = client.submit_proof(challenge, proof)

challenge := "the-challenge-code-from-user"
proof, _ := client.Sign(challenge)
result, _ := client.SubmitProof(context.Background(), challenge, proof)

tether sign "the-challenge-code-from-user"
tether check "the-challenge-code-from-user"

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
All SDKs support configuration via environment variables:

Variable Used by Description TETHER_CREDENTIAL_ID SDKs, CLI, MCP Your credential ID TETHER_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH SDKs, CLI, MCP Path to your RSA private key

docs.title: 1. Create an Account
docs.text: Go to tether.name/auth and enter your email. You'll receive a magic code — no passwords.

docs.title: 2. Create a Credential
docs.text:
From the dashboard, click New Agent and give it a name. You'll receive:

  • A Credential ID
  • A Registration Token

Save both — the registration token is shown only once.

docs.title: 3. Generate and Register Keys
docs.text:
Your agent needs to generate an RSA-2048 key pair and register the public key with Tether.

Node.jsPythonGo 
import { TetherClient } from 'tether-name';

const client = new TetherClient({
  credentialId: 'your-credential-id',
  privateKeyPath: '/path/to/private-key.der'
});

from tether_name import TetherClient

client = TetherClient(
    credential_id="your-credential-id",
    private_key_path="/path/to/private-key.der"
)

import tether "github.com/tether-name/tether-name-go"

client, err := tether.NewClient(tether.Options{
    CredentialID:   "your-credential-id",
    PrivateKeyPath: "/path/to/private-key.der",
})

docs.title: 4. Store Your Keys Safely
docs.text:
• Keep the private key file secure — treat it like an SSH key
  • The key should be readable only by the agent process
  • Never commit private keys to version control
  • Add *.der and *.pem to your .gitignore

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
go get github.com/tether-name/tether-name-go

Requires Go 1.22+. Zero external dependencies — uses only the Go standard library.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
package main

import (
    "context"
    "fmt"
    "log"

    tether "github.com/tether-name/tether-name-go"
)

func main() {
    client, err := tether.NewClient(tether.Options{
        CredentialID:   "your-credential-id",
        PrivateKeyPath: "/path/to/private-key.der",
    })
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    result, err := client.Verify(context.Background())
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    fmt.Println(result.Verified)
    fmt.Println(result.AgentName)
}

docs.title: Step-by-Step Verification
docs.text:
ctx := context.Background()

// 1. Request a challenge
challenge, err := client.RequestChallenge(ctx)

// 2. Sign the challenge
proof, err := client.Sign(challenge)

// 3. Submit proof
result, err := client.SubmitProof(ctx, challenge, proof)

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
client, err := tether.NewClient(tether.Options{
    // Authentication — choose one:

    // Option 1: API key (for agent management and credential operations)
    ApiKey: "sk-tether-name-...",

    // Option 2: Credential + private key (for verification and signing)
    CredentialID: "your-credential-id",
    PrivateKeyPath: "/path/to/key.der",  // File path (DER or PEM)
    PrivateKeyPEM:  pemBytes,             // PEM as []byte
    PrivateKeyDER:  derBytes,             // DER as []byte
})

When ApiKey is set, CredentialID and private key options become optional. A private key is still required for Verify() and Sign().

Environment variables:

  • TETHER_API_KEY
  • TETHER_CREDENTIAL_ID
  • TETHER_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH

docs.title: Agent Management
docs.text:
One line to start managing agents programmatically:

client, err := tether.NewClient(tether.Options{
    ApiKey: "sk-tether-name-...",
})

// Create an agent
agent, err := client.CreateAgent(ctx, "my-bot", "")
fmt.Println(agent.ID)

// List all agents
agents, err := client.ListAgents(ctx)

// Delete an agent
err = client.DeleteAgent(ctx, agent.ID)

docs.title: tether.NewClient(opts Options) (*TetherClient, error)
docs.text: Creates a new client. Returns an error if neither ApiKey nor CredentialID is provided.

docs.title: client.CreateAgent(ctx, agentName, description) (*Agent, error)
docs.text: Create a new agent credential. Requires API key auth.

docs.title: client.ListAgents(ctx) ([]Agent, error)
docs.text: List all agent credentials. Requires API key auth.

docs.title: client.DeleteAgent(ctx, credentialID) (bool, error)
docs.text: Delete an agent credential. Requires API key auth.

docs.title: client.Verify(ctx) (*VerificationResult, error)
docs.text: Complete verification flow. Requests a challenge, signs it, and submits proof.

docs.title: client.RequestChallenge(ctx) (string, error)
docs.text: Request a new challenge from the Tether API.

docs.title: client.Sign(challenge) (string, error)
docs.text:
Sign a challenge string with the configured private key.

Returns: URL-safe base64 signature (no padding).

docs.title: client.SubmitProof(ctx, challenge, proof) (*VerificationResult, error)
docs.text: Submit a signed proof for verification.

docs.title: Types
docs.text:
type VerificationResult struct {
    Verified        bool
    AgentName       string
    VerifyURL       string
    Email           string
    RegisteredSince *time.Time
    Error           string
    Challenge       string
}

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
import "errors"

result, err := client.Verify(ctx)
if err != nil {
    var apiErr *tether.APIError
    var verifyErr *tether.VerificationError
    var keyErr *tether.KeyLoadError

    switch {
    case errors.As(err, &apiErr):
        fmt.Printf("API error (status %d): %s\n", apiErr.StatusCode, apiErr.Message)
    case errors.As(err, &verifyErr):
        fmt.Printf("Verification failed: %s\n", verifyErr.Message)
    case errors.As(err, &keyErr):
        fmt.Printf("Key error: %s\n", keyErr.Message)
    }
}

Sentinel errors for errors.Is():

  • tether.ErrAPI — API communication error
  • tether.ErrVerification — Verification failure
  • tether.ErrKeyLoad — Private key loading error

docs.title: Install

npm install tether-name

Requires Node.js 18+. Zero runtime dependencies — uses only Node.js built-in crypto and fetch.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
import { TetherClient } from 'tether-name';

const client = new TetherClient({
  credentialId: 'your-credential-id',
  privateKeyPath: '/path/to/private-key.der'
});

// Full verification in one call
const result = await client.verify();

// Or step by step
const challenge = await client.requestChallenge();
const proof = client.sign(challenge);
const result = await client.submitProof(challenge, proof);

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
const client = new TetherClient({
  // Authentication — choose one:

  // Option 1: API key (for agent management and credential operations)
  apiKey: 'sk-tether-name-...',

  // Option 2: Credential + private key (for verification and signing)
  credentialId: 'your-credential-id',
  privateKeyPath: '/path/to/key.der',  // File path (DER or PEM)
  privateKeyPem: '-----BEGIN...',       // PEM string
  privateKeyBuffer: buffer,             // DER buffer
});

When apiKey is set, credentialId and private key options become optional. A private key is still required for verify() and sign().

Environment variables:

  • TETHER_API_KEY
  • TETHER_CREDENTIAL_ID
  • TETHER_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH

docs.title: Agent Management
docs.text:
One line to start managing agents programmatically:

const client = new TetherClient({ apiKey: 'sk-tether-name-...' });

// Create an agent
const agent = await client.createAgent('my-bot');
console.log(agent.id);

// List all agents
const agents = await client.listAgents();

// Delete an agent
await client.deleteAgent(agent.id);

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
import { TetherError, TetherAPIError, TetherVerificationError } from 'tether-name';

try {
  const result = await client.verify();
} catch (error) {
  if (error instanceof TetherAPIError) {
    console.error(`API error: ${error.status} - ${error.message}`);
  } else if (error instanceof TetherVerificationError) {
    console.error(`Verification failed: ${error.message}`);
  }
}

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
pip install tether-name

Requires Python 3.8+.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
from tether_name import TetherClient

client = TetherClient(
    credential_id="your-credential-id",
    private_key_path="/path/to/private-key.der"
)

# Full verification in one call
result = client.verify()

# Or step by step
challenge = client.request_challenge()
proof = client.sign(challenge)
result = client.submit_proof(challenge, proof)

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
client = TetherClient(
    # Authentication — choose one:

    # Option 1: API key (for agent management and credential operations)
    api_key="sk-tether-name-...",

    # Option 2: Credential + private key (for verification and signing)
    credential_id="your-credential-id",
    private_key_path="/path/to/key.der",     # File path (DER or PEM)
    private_key_pem="-----BEGIN...",          # PEM string or bytes
    private_key_der=b"...",                   # DER bytes
)

When api_key is set, credential_id and private key options become optional. A private key is still required for verify() and sign().

Environment variables:

  • TETHER_API_KEY
  • TETHER_CREDENTIAL_ID
  • TETHER_PRIVATE_KEY_PATH

docs.title: Context Manager
docs.text:
with TetherClient(credential_id="...", private_key_path="...") as client:
    result = client.verify()
# HTTP client automatically closed

client = TetherClient(api_key="sk-tether-name-...")

# Create an agent
agent = client.create_agent("my-bot")
print(agent.id)

# List all agents
agents = client.list_agents()

# Delete an agent

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
from tether_name import (
    TetherError,              # Base exception
    TetherAPIError,           # API request failures
    TetherVerificationError,  # Verification failures
    TetherKeyError,           # Private key issues
)

try:
    result = client.verify()
except TetherAPIError as e:
    print(f"API error {e.status_code}: {e.message}")
except TetherVerificationError as e:
    print(f"Verification failed: {e.message}")
except TetherKeyError as e:
    print(f"Key error: {e.message}")
